definitions.definition: not done, seen, happening, etc. very often
definitions.sensetop: it is rare for somebody/something to do somethingit is rare to do something

examples.text: a **rare disease/occurrence/event**
This weekend, visitors will get a rare chance to visit the private apartments.
It's extremely rare for it to be this hot in April.
examples.contextForm: it is rare for somebody/something to do something

examples.text: It is rare to find such loyalty these days.
examples.contextForm: it is rare to do something

examples.text: **On the rare occasions when** they met he hardly even dared speak to her.
The bacteria can cause infection and, in **rare cases**, blindness.
The current exhibition offers a **rare opportunity** to see his original drawings.
In a **rare moment** of candour, she admitted that mistakes had been made.
It was a rare *(= very great)* honour to be made a fellow of the college.
Most documentaries, with few rare exceptions, aren't worth purchasing.
Serious crime is a relatively rare occurrence here.
Cold spells in Britain are becoming increasingly rare.
He suffers from a rare bone disease.
It is rare for a prison sentence to be imposed for a first offence.
The case provides a rare glimpse into police practice.
The hatching of a baby tortoise in captivity is a rare event.
Then I had one of my rare good ideas.
Rare cases of humans being infected with the virus that causes bird flu have been reported.
This is a rare sight: badgers are normally active only at night.

definitions.definition: existing only in small numbers and therefore valuable or interesting

examples.text: a **rare book**
a rare coin/stamp
a rare plant/bird/animal
This **species** is extremely **rare**.
The stamps were not rare enough to be interesting.
The jade vase was extremely rare and very valuable.
The library has a collection of rare books and manuscripts.
The marshes contain many rare species of plants.

definitions.definition: cooked for only a short time so that the inside is still red

examples.text: ‘How would you like your steak?’ ‘Rare.’

wordOrigin: senses 1 to 2 late Middle English (in the sense ‘widely spaced, infrequent’): from Latin rarus.sense 3 late 18th cent.: variant of obsolete rear ‘half-cooked’ (used to refer to soft-boiled eggs, from the mid 17th to mid 19th cents).
